title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #648: Decreasing Greatest Prime Factors**

Let g(n) be the longest increasing sequence below n with strictly decreasing greatest prime factors.

**Status**: SOLVED (Cambie 2025)

**Answer**: g(n) ≍ (n/log n)^(1/2)

title: Greatest Prime Factor
content:
**greatestPrimeFactor n**: P(n) = greatest prime factor of n.

Returns 1 if n ≤ 1.

Defined as max of prime factors.

title: GPF of Prime
content:
**gpf_prime**: P(p) = p for any prime p.

The only prime factor of a prime is itself.

title: GPF Divides
content:
**gpf_dvd**: P(n) | n for n ≥ 2.

The greatest prime factor divides the number.

title: GPF is Prime
content:
**gpf_is_prime**: P(n) is prime for n ≥ 2.

By definition of prime factorization.

title: GPF of Product
content:
**gpf_mul_ge**: P(ab) ≥ max(P(a), P(b)).

The GPF of a product is at least the max of the factors' GPFs.

title: Smooth Numbers
content:
**IsSmooth n y**: n is y-smooth if P(n) ≤ y.

Smooth numbers have bounded greatest prime factor.

title: Smooth Count
content:
**smoothCount x y**: Ψ(x,y) = count of y-smooth numbers ≤ x.

This is a fundamental counting function in analytic number theory.

title: De Bruijn Estimate
content:
**de_bruijn_estimate**: Ψ(x,y) ≈ x · ρ(u) where u = log x / log y.

The Dickman-de Bruijn function ρ controls smooth number counts.

title: Decreasing GPF Sequence
content:
**DecreasingGPFSeq n**: A sequence a₁ < a₂ < ... < aₜ < n with P(a₁) > P(a₂) > ... > P(aₜ).

Integers increase, greatest prime factors decrease.

This is the central structure of the problem.

title: Function g(n)
content:
**g n**: Maximum length of a decreasing GPF sequence below n.

This is the extremal function the problem asks about.

title: Example: 6, 4
content:
**example_seq_6_4**: P(6) > P(4), i.e., 3 > 2.

The sequence 6, 4 has increasing values but decreasing GPF.

title: Small Values
content:
**g_ge_one, g_ge_two**: Basic lower bounds.

g(n) ≥ 1 for n ≥ 3
g(n) ≥ 2 for n ≥ 5

title: Powers of 2
content:
**gpf_power_of_two**: P(2^k) = 2 for k ≥ 1.

Powers of 2 have the smallest possible GPF.

Useful for ending sequences.

title: Distinct GPF Values
content:
**distinct_gpf_values**: All GPF values in a sequence are distinct.

Since P(aᵢ) > P(aᵢ₊₁), the GPF values form a strictly decreasing sequence.

title: Prime Counting Bound
content:
**gpf_values_bounded_by_primes, g_le_pi**: g(n) ≤ π(n).

Sequence length is bounded by the number of primes up to n.

This is a trivial upper bound.

title: Upper Bound
content:
**g_upper_bound**: g(n) ≤ 3√(n/log n).

Cambie's upper bound on the extremal function.

The key is counting smooth numbers appropriately.

title: Construction Lower Bound
content:
**primePowerSeq, construction_lower_bound**: g(n) ≥ 2√(n/log n).

Explicit construction achieves this bound.

Uses powers of consecutive primes.

title: Cambie's Theorem
content:
**cambie_theorem (2025)**: g(n) ≍ (n/log n)^(1/2).

2√(n/log n) ≤ g(n) ≤ 3√(n/log n)

The main result solving Erdős #648.

title: Exponent and Base
content:
**cambie_exponent**: 1/2
**cambie_base n**: n/log n

The growth is √(n/log n).

title: Constant Question
content:
**CambieConstantQuestion**: Does g(n) ~ c√(n/log n) for some constant c?

Asks whether the limit g(n)/√(n/log n) exists.

title: Constant Bounds
content:
**constant_bounds**: If c exists, then c ∈ [2, 2√2].

**c_lower** = 2
**c_upper** = 2√2 ≈ 2.83

**c_upper_approx**: 2√2 < 3.

title: Terms are Smooth
content:
**term_is_smooth**: Each term aᵢ is P(aᵢ)-smooth.

**smooth_numbers_provide_candidates**: Smooth numbers give sequence candidates.

Key connection to smooth number theory.

title: Smallest Prime Factor
content:
**smallestPrimeFactor n**: p(n) = smallest prime factor.

**spf_le_gpf**: p(n) ≤ P(n) always.
**spf_eq_gpf_prime**: p(n) = P(n) for primes.

Dual to greatest prime factor.

title: Squarefree
content:
**Squarefree n**: No prime squared divides n.

Squarefree numbers have distinct prime factors.

title: OEIS Connection
content:
**oeis_A391750**: OEIS sequence A391750 = values of g(n).

**oeis_small_values**: g(10) ≥ 2, g(100) ≥ 4, g(1000) ≥ 8.

title: Main Result
content:
**erdos_648**: Erdős Problem #648 is SOLVED.

Question: What is the asymptotic behavior of g(n)?

Answer: g(n) ≍ (n/log n)^(1/2)

Solved by Stijn Cambie (2025).

title: Final Answer
content:
**erdos_648_answer**: "SOLVED: g(n) ≍ (n/log n)^(1/2), constant c ∈ [2, 2√2] (Cambie 2025)"

**erdos_648_status**: "SOLVED by Stijn Cambie (2025)"
